refined_goal: Build a Crossâ€‘World Agent Harness that treats GUIs, terminals, web apps, and physics simulators as one unified â€œembodied environment,â€ controllable via the same policy and orchestrated through Model Context Protocol (MCP). Concretely: an MCP server mesh coordinating Genesis (physics) + SeleniumBase (DOM/UI) + egui (native GUI) + Microsoft Terminal (CLI panes) + exo (multiâ€‘device runners), with a Universal Actionâ€‘Observation Graph and adapters that map mouse/keyboard/DOM events to robot endâ€‘effector actions and back. Success = a single policy (DAgger + BC, then DreamerV3 fineâ€‘tuning) completes endâ€‘toâ€‘end tasks across three modalities (robotic pickâ€‘andâ€‘place, web form flow, CLI workflow) with â‰¥85% success and â‰¤1.2Ã— realâ€‘time latency, bundling reproducible runs via pearâ€‘desktop and video highlights via losslessâ€‘cut. This matters because it collapses fragmented test/automation stacks into one agentic substrateâ€”usable for CI, QA, and embodied AIâ€”making complex, crossâ€‘surface automation reliably portable and verifiable.
repository_synergy:
THE INSIGHT: UI automation and embodied robotics are the same problem in disguiseâ€”partial observability, noisy control, event timing, and reward shapingâ€”just with different physics: DOM has layout/render physics; a terminal has pacing/echo physics; Genesis has rigidâ€‘body physics. If we normalize these into a Universal Actionâ€‘Observation Graph (UAOG), one policy can traverse all three. That unlocks crossâ€‘modality generalization previously siloed across QA tools and robot simulators. MCP becomes the lingua franca to route agent actions to whichever â€œworldâ€ is active.

THE STORY: modelcontextprotocol/servers gives us a clean control planeâ€”expose tools as streaming MCP servers that LLMs and agents can invoke. Genesis-Embodied-AI/Genesis provides a rich physics sandbox with headless rendering, perfect for actionâ€‘latency benchmarking and curriculum generation. emilk/egui offers a native, immediateâ€‘mode GUI we can compile to desktop or WebAssemblyâ€”a controllable, lowâ€‘latency target app to validate our GUI adapters without the variability of a browser. seleniumbase/SeleniumBase is our DOM manipulator and observer; with a thin UAOG adapter, pointer/key/DOM are firstâ€‘class actions. microsoft/terminal is the multiplexed terminal substrateâ€”give the agent a CLI â€œworldâ€ with multiple panes as spatial anchors. exo-explore/exo coordinates multiâ€‘device, multiâ€‘GPU runs, distributing rollouts across worlds. harness/harness supplies pipeline semantics to package and trigger endâ€‘toâ€‘end experiments via simple DAGs. pear-devs/pear-desktop becomes the P2P artifact carrierâ€”bundle environments, traces, policies, and highlight videos to share reproducibility offline. mifi/lossless-cut is creatively repurposed as a headless highlight extractor for long rolloutsâ€”autoâ€‘cuts by reward spikes or anomaly flags. codelucas/newspaper seeds realâ€‘world scenario generatorsâ€”scrape checkout flows or form patterns that synthesize adversarial web tasks. jeecgboot/JeecgBoot spins disposable enterprise apps with predictable entitiesâ€”great for repeatable, complex UI workflows. vadimdemedes/ink renders a live orchestrator CLI with rich realâ€‘time dashboards inside Terminal. veggiemonk/awesome-docker, avelino/awesome-go, vuejs/awesome-vue, vsouza/awesome-ios together are our longâ€‘tail target corpusâ€”programmatically pick representative apps/libs to diversify tasks. auchenberg/volkswagen is flipped: not to cheat CI, but to inject â€œcheat detectionâ€ tasks that probe whether policies overfit telemetry.

THE SYNERGY: By forcing every surface (physics, DOM, GUI, terminal) through the same action bus and timestamped observation schema, we can share data, curriculum, and even policies. A DOM click becomes a 2D endâ€‘effector move with dwell time; a terminal keystroke is a precise torque impulse on the TTY state machine. Genesis gives us pretraining of stateâ€‘estimation and control that transfer to GUI timing and hover stability; SeleniumBaseâ€™s DOM diffs fuel reward design that in turn accelerates manipulation curricula in Genesis via shaped rewards.

THE INNOVATION: Crossâ€‘world curriculum: train hovering stability in Genesis, then apply to pixelâ€‘perfect button selection in egui and web, reducing flakiness. Unified regression artifacts: one bundle contains rollouts from robot, web, and CLI with synchronized timelines; losslessâ€‘cut autoâ€‘extracts comparable segments for triage. The illicit bridge is treating DOM/terminal timing as physicsâ€”making classical RL control tricks (PIDâ€‘like smoothing, actionâ€‘repeat, domain randomization) immediately useful for flaky UI automation. MCP is the switchboard that lets an LLM strategize, while the policy executes lowâ€‘level control across any world.

THE BRIDGE: UAOG adapters are the contraband glue: DOM2Physics (SeleniumBase â†’ pointer dynamics), TTY2Dynamics (Terminal â†’ keystroke dynamics), EGUI2Genesis (egui widget constraints â†’ collisionâ€‘like hitâ€‘tests). volkswagen becomes the canaryâ€”injects misleading â€œpassâ€ cues (green badges, CI env vars) to verify the agent relies on ground truth outcomes, not superficial telemetry. JeecgBoot provides everâ€‘fresh enterprise graphs that stress dataâ€‘consistency and multiâ€‘step business logicâ€”exactly the hard part typical web QA avoids, but our crossâ€‘world agent can master. The result: a single, portable agentic harness for everything from robotic pickâ€‘andâ€‘place to SAPâ€‘like workflows, shareable as P2P bundles.
technical_architecture:
Core components and data flow:

- UAOG (Universal Actionâ€‘Observation Graph):
  - Action schema: {type: pointer|key|dom|tty|effector, target: selector|xy|pane|link_pose, params: {...}, ts_ns}.
  - Observation schema: {rgb: optional, dom_tree_hash, egui_tree, tty_buf, proprio: Genesis state, layout_boxes, focus_chain, ts_ns}.
  - Transport: gRPC over Unix sockets for lowâ€‘latency local; WebSocket for remote; capped at 120 Hz action application with actionâ€‘repeat (k=2..4) to smooth spiky policies.

- MCP Orchestrator:
  - Tools: genesis.run(env_spec), selenium.play(flow_spec), egui.app.spawn(bin|wasm), terminal.panes(config), exo.schedule(job), harness.pipeline(dag), lossless.cut(file, cues), pear.bundle(path), newspaper.scrape(url|query), jeecgboot.scaffold(schema), volkswagen.inject(profile).
  - Session graph: A plan (from LLM or human) resolved into a DAG of tool calls with streaming tokens for observations.

- World adapters:
  - DOM2Physics: Wrap SeleniumBase; every action is applied as pointer trajectory with velocity/acceleration constraints; DOM snapshots produce layout_boxes with zâ€‘order and hover thresholds. Antiâ€‘flakiness: oversample near edges; friction model for scroll.
  - EGUI2Genesis: Mirror widget bounds to virtual obstacles; pointerâ†’contact mapping; leverage egui immediateâ€‘mode state to detect intent vs accidental hover.
  - TTY2Dynamics: Terminal pane as discrete time dynamics; keystroke debouncing, echo delay model; pane coordinates act as spatial anchors for an attention policy.
  - Genesis: Headless at 240 Hz sim; render 30/60 fps; curriculum randomization (lighting, texture) mirrored to UI (DOM font/contrast randomization) to encourage invariance.

- Policy and learning:
  - Stage 1: Behavior Cloning + DAgger from scripted experts (SeleniumBase for DOM, Harness pipelines for CLI, Genesis scripted controllers).
  - Stage 2: DreamerV3 fineâ€‘tuning unified across worlds via shared latent world model; domain tags gating slight final layers per world (adapter heads).
  - Reward shaping: DOM goal achieved (XPath/ARIA), CLI state diff (pane regex), Genesis task success. Uniform time penalties; smoothness bonuses.

- Execution and scaling:
  - exo schedules concurrent rollouts across hosts/GPUs (Genesis training, parallel Selenium browsers with xvfb, egui native app instances).
  - harness orchestrates endâ€‘toâ€‘end DAGs: scaffold apps (JeecgBoot), deploy containers (awesome-docker images), run policies, collect artifacts.
  - microsoft/terminal hosts orchestrator panes: Ink CLI dashboard, live logs, UAOG scope, preview video.

- Observability and artifacts:
  - Synchronized trace bus (nanosecond timestamps). Record raw observations, actions, rewards, DOM/egui trees.
  - Video: compositor assembles splitâ€‘view (world + cursor heatmap + DOM overlays). mifi/lossless-cut runs headless with cue sheets derived from reward spikes/anomalies to extract 10â€“30s highlights.
  - Packaging: pearâ€‘desktop bundles the entire run: containers, seeds, traces, model snapshot, highlight reels; P2P seed for offline sharing.

- Scenario generation:
  - codelucas/newspaper scrapes real workflows (e.g., checkout forms) to synthesize DOM targets.
  - jeecgboot scaffolds CRUD+workflow apps with synthetic data; actions become multiâ€‘step business sequences.
  - awesomeâ€‘{docker,go,vue,ios} curated lists provide longâ€‘tail targetsâ€”random sampling for robustness sweeps.
  - auchenberg/volkswagen inject tasks that present deceptive pass signals; regression if policy relies on them.

Key challenges and solutions:
- Timebase alignment across worlds: global ts_ns and actionâ€‘repeat; worldâ€‘specific latency compensation via Kalman filter on cursor/echo.
- Flakiness: physicsâ€‘inspired smoothing on pointer and TTY; edge oversampling; DOM hover hysteresis.
- Performance: zeroâ€‘copy frame sharing via shared memory for local render; WebGPU for egui WASM; xvfb tuned to 60 fps; Genesis headless to maximize sim FPS.
- API granularity: MCP tool calls are coarse (start/stop), UAOG is fineâ€‘grained streaming over gRPC for lowâ€‘latency control.
- Licensing: isolate GPL losslessâ€‘cut into optional service; artifacts tagged; replacement via FFmpeg possible.
expected_impact:
Use cases uniquely enabled by this crossâ€‘world harness:

1) Flakeâ€‘proof Web Checkout Replays: Train a policy on Genesis hover stability; transfer to SeleniumBase to click pixelâ€‘tight DOM elements under randomized fonts/contrast. Cuts regression triage videos with cursor heat maps, bundled via pear for offline QA signâ€‘off.

2) Terminalâ€‘Backed Ops Playbooks: Define a pipeline that opens three terminal panes (logs, kubectl, editor). The agent executes incident playbooks endâ€‘toâ€‘end, with TTY2Dynamics handling echo delays. Ink dashboard shows live intent; volkswagen injects fake â€œall greenâ€ banners to ensure reliance on log content, not color.

3) Enterprise CRUD Workflows at Scale: JeecgBoot spins a fresh HR or inventory app; the agent completes multiâ€‘screen workflows, verifying data consistency across list/detail/report views. Seeds and bundles make failures 100% reproducible across teams.

4) Crossâ€‘Modal Skill Distillation: Teach precise dragâ€‘andâ€‘drop in Genesis; distill to egui and web drag behaviors, eliminating microâ€‘jitter that causes UI test failures. Measurably reduces flake rate by >40% in randomized UI skins.

5) Longâ€‘Tail Robustness Sweeps: Autoâ€‘sample apps from awesomeâ€‘vue/awesomeâ€‘go/awesomeâ€‘ios; launch containerized demos with awesomeâ€‘docker guidance; the agent validates create/open/save flows across stacks, collecting coverage metrics and highlighting brittle libraries.

6) Newsâ€‘Driven Scenario Fuzzer: Use newspaper to scrape trending fintech or travel flows; synthesize adversarial forms (edge validators, timeouts) and run nightly sweeps. Bundle failures with losslessâ€‘cut reels for stakeholders.

7) Offline Field Debugging: P2P share a failing scenario bundle to an airâ€‘gapped environment; same policy, same containers, same traces. No cloud dependence.

Limitations and mitigations:
- iOS automation depth may be limitedâ€”start with simulators and webviews; define adapters later.
- Dreamer transfer may need adapter heads per worldâ€”keep shared trunk, small heads.
- GPL concerns from losslessâ€‘cutâ€”optional service with FFmpeg fallback.
- Browser nondeterminismâ€”use UAOG smoothing and deterministic seeds where possible.
- Resource intensityâ€”exo schedules efficiently; headless modes reduce overhead.
innovation_analysis: Innovation score: 9.1/10. We recast UI/terminal automation as embodied control, unify worlds with UAOG, and use MCP as an agentic switchboard. The illicit linkâ€”DOM/TTY as physicsâ€”yields transferable control policies and shared curriculum across modalities. Immediate next steps: 1) Implement UAOG schema and gRPC bus; 2) Build DOM2Physics and TTY2Dynamics adapters; 3) Stand up MCP tools for Genesis, SeleniumBase, egui, Terminal; 4) Create a minimal JeecgBoot workflow scenario; 5) Wire losslessâ€‘cut headless extraction; 6) Package via pear and validate reproducibility. Key metrics: crossâ€‘world task success (>85%), latency (<1.2Ã— realâ€‘time), flake reduction (>40%), bundle reproducibility (100%), deceptionâ€‘robustness (no false passes under volkswagen probes). Essential stack: Python (Genesis/SeleniumBase), Rust (egui), Go (harness), TypeScript (MCP/Ink), Docker/Xvfb/WebGPU, gRPC/WebSocket, pearâ€‘desktop.

sources.name: modelcontextprotocol/servers
sources.readme_snippet:
# Model Context Protocol servers

This repository is a collection of *reference implementations* for the [Model Context Protocol](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/) (MCP), as well as references to community-built servers and additional resources.

The servers in this repository showcase the versatility and extensibility of MCP, demonstrating how it can be used to give Large Language Models (LLMs) secure, controlled access to tools and data sources.
Typically, each MCP server is implemented with an MCP SDK:

- [C# MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/csharp-sdk)
- [Go MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/go-sdk)
- [Java MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/java-sdk)
- [Kotlin MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/kotlin-sdk)
- [PHP MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/php-sdk)
- [Python MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk)
- [Ruby MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/ruby-sdk)
- [Rust MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/rust-sdk)
- [Swift MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/swift-sdk)
- [TypeScript MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/typescript-sdk)

> [!NOTE]
> Lists in this README are maintained in alphabetical order to minimize merge conflicts when adding new items.

## ğŸŒŸ Reference Servers

These servers aim to demonstrate MCP features and the official SDKs.

- **[Everything](src/everything)** - Reference / test server with prompts, resources, and tools.
- **[Fetch](src/fetch)** - Web content fetching and conversion for efficient LLM usage.
- **[Filesystem](src/filesystem)** - Secure file operations with configurable access controls.
- **[Git](src/git)** - Tools to read, search, and manipulate Git repositories.
- **[Memory](src/memory)** - Knowledge graph-based persistent memory system.
- **[Sequential Thinking](src/sequentialthinking)** - Dynamic and reflective problem-solving through thought sequences.
- **[Time](src/time)** - Time

egui development is sponsored by [Rerun](https://www.rerun.io/), a startup building
an SDK for visualizing streams of multimodal data.
--- ğŸ‘‰ [Click to run the web demo](https://www.egui.rs/#demo) ğŸ‘ˆ egui (pronounced "e-gooey") is a simple, fast, and highly portable immediate mode GUI library for Rust. egui runs on the web, natively, and [in your favorite game engine](#integrations). egui aims to be the easiest-to-use Rust GUI library, and the simplest way to make a web app in Rust. egui can be used anywhere you can draw textured triangles, which means you can easily integrate it into your game engine of choice. [`eframe`](https://github.com/emilk/egui/tree/main/crates/eframe) is the official egui framework, which supports writing apps for Web, Linux, Mac, Windows, and Android. ## Example ``` rust ui.heading("My egui Application"); ui.horizontal(

sources.name: harness/harness
sources.readme_snippet:
# Harness
Harness Open Source is an open source development platform packed with the power of code hosting, automated DevOps pipelines, hosted development environments (Gitspaces), and artifact registries.

## Overview
Harness Open source is an open source development platform packed with the power of code hosting, automated DevOps pipelines, Gitspaces, and artifact registries.


## Running Harness locally
> The latest publicly released docker image can be found on [harness/harness](https://hub.docker.com/r/harness/harness).

To install Harness yourself, simply run the command below. Once the container is up, you can visit http://localhost:3000 in your browser.

```bash
docker run -d \
  -p 3000:3000 \
  -p 3022:3022 \
  -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock \
  -v /tmp/harness:/data \
  --name harness \
  --restart always \
  harness/harness
```
> The Harness image uses a volume to store the database and repositories. It is highly recommended to use a bind mount or named volume as otherwise all data will be lost once the container is stopped.

See [developer.harness.io](https://developer.harness.io/docs/open-source) to learn how to get the most out of Harness.

## Where is Drone?

Harness Open Source represents a massive investment in the next generation of Drone. Where Drone focused solely on continuous integration, Harness adds source code hosting, developer environments (gitspaces), and artifact registries; providing teams with an end-to-end, open source DevOps platform.

The goal is for Harness to eventually be at full parity with Drone in terms of pipeline capabilities, allowing users to seamlessly migrate from Drone to Harness.

But, we expect this to take some time, which is why we took a snapshot of Drone as a feature branch [drone](https://github.com/harness/harness/tree/drone) ([README](https://github.com/harness/harness/blob/drone/.github/readme.md)) so it can continue development.

As for Harness, the development is taking place on the [main](htt

sources.name: mifi/lossless-cut
sources.readme_snippet:
Special thanks to:

Warp, built for coding with multiple AI agents
Available for macOS, Linux and Windows


LosslessCut

The swiss army knife of lossless video/audio editing


Thanks to my supporters and everyone who purchased LosslessCut!



LosslessCut aims to be the ultimate cross platform FFmpeg GUI for extremely fast and lossless operations on video, audio, subtitle and other related media files. The main feature is lossless trimming and cutting of video and audio files, which is great for saving space by rough-cutting your large video files taken from a video camera, GoPro, drone, etc. It lets you quickly extract the good parts from your videos and discard many gigabytes of data without doing a slow re-encode and thereby losing quality. exo: Run your own AI cluster at home with everyday devices. Maintained by [exo labs](https://x.com/exolabs).

[Discord](https://discord.gg/EUnjGpsmWw) | [Telegram](https://t.me/+Kh-KqHTzFYg3MGNk) | [X](https://x.com/exolabs)

[![GitHub Repo stars](https://img.shields.io/github/stars/exo-explore/exo)](https://github.com/exo-explore/exo/stargazers) [![Tests](https://dl.circleci.com/status-badge/img/circleci/TrkofJDoGzdQAeL6yVHKsg/4i5hJuafuwZYZQxbRAWS71/tree/main.svg?style=svg)](https://dl.circleci.com/status-badge/redirect/circleci/TrkofJDoGzdQAeL6yVHKsg/4i5hJuafuwZYZQxbRAWS71/tree/main) [![License: GPL v3](https://img.shields.io/badge/License-GPLv3-blue.svg)](https://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-3.0)
--- > **EXO** > > EXO started out of a desire to run research experiments on large language models using the hardware we already owned. > > What began here is becoming part of something much larger. > > soonâ„¢ > > \- The EXO Team --- --ify your existing devices into one powerful GPU: iPhone, iPad, Android, Mac, NVIDIA, Raspberry Pi, pretty much any device!

Update: exo is hiring. See here for more details.

## Get Involved exo is **experimental** software. Expect bugs early on. Create issues so they can be fixed. The [exo labs](https://x.com/exolabs) team will strive to resolve issues quickly. We also welcome contributions from the community. We have a list of bounties in [this sheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1cTCpTIp48UnnI

sources.name: veggiemonk/awesome-docker
sources.readme_snippet:
# Awesome Docker [![Awesome](https://cdn.rawgit.com/sindresorhus/awesome/d7305f38d29fed78fa85652e3a63e154dd8e8829/media/badge.svg)][sindresorhus] [![Netlify Status](https://api.netlify.com/api/v1/badges/8ca86717-11ba-46d4-9d0a-700d8527f13b/deploy-status)](https://app.netlify.com/sites/awesome-docker/deploys)[![Track Awesome List](https://www.trackawesomelist.com/badge.svg)](https://www.trackawesomelist.com/veggiemonk/awesome-docker/)[![Last Commit](https://img.shields.io/github/last-commit/veggiemonk/awesome-docker)](https://github.com/veggiemonk/awesome-docker/commits/main)<!-- omit in toc -->

> A curated list of Docker resources and projects

If you would like to contribute, please read [CONTRIBUTING.md][contributing] first.
It contains a lot of tips and guidelines to help keep things organized.
Just click [README.md][editreadme] to submit a [pull request][editreadme].
If this list is not complete, you can [contribute][editreadme] to make it so. Here is a great video tutorial to learn how to [contribute on Github](https://egghead.io/lessons/javascript-identifying-how-to-contribute-to-an-open-source-project-on-github).

> **Please**, help organize these resources so that they are _easy to find_ and _understand_ for newcomers. See how to **[Contribute][contributing]** for tips!

**_If you see a link here that is not (any longer) a good fit, you can fix it by submitting a [pull request][editreadme] to improve this file. Thank you!_**

The creators and maintainers of this list do not receive any form of payment to accept a change made by any contributor. This page is not an official Docker product in any way. It is a list of links to projects and is maintained by volunteers. Everybody is welcome to contribute. The goal of this repo is to index open-source projects, not to advertise for profit.

All the links are monitored and tested with a home baked [Node.js script](https://github.com/veggiemonk/awesome-docker/blob/master/.github/workflows/pull_request.yml)

# Conte

sources.name: codelucas/newspaper
sources.readme_snippet:
Newspaper3k: Article scraping & curation
========================================

.. image:: https://badge.fury.io/py/newspaper3k.svg
    :target: http://badge.fury.io/py/newspaper3k.svg
        :alt: Latest version

.. image:: https://travis-ci.org/codelucas/newspaper.svg
        :target: http://travis-ci.org/codelucas/newspaper/
        :alt: Build status

.. image:: https://coveralls.io/repos/github/codelucas/newspaper/badge.svg?branch=master
        :target: https://coveralls.io/github/codelucas/newspaper
        :alt: Coverage status


Inspired by `requests`_ for its simplicity and powered by `lxml`_ for its speed:

    "Newspaper is an amazing python library for extracting & curating articles."
    -- `tweeted by`_ Kenneth Reitz, Author of `requests`_

    "Newspaper delivers Instapaper style article extraction." -- `The Changelog`_

.. _`tweeted by`: https://twitter.com/kennethreitz/status/419520678862548992
.. _`The Changelog`: http://thechangelog.com/newspaper-delivers-instapaper-style-article-extraction/

**Newspaper is a Python3 library**! Or, view our **deprecated and buggy** `Python2 branch`_

.. _`Python2 branch`: https://github.com/codelucas/newspaper/tree/python-2-head

A Glance:
---------

.. code-block:: pycon

    >>> from newspaper import Article

    >>> url = 'http://fox13now.com/2013/12/30/new-year-new-laws-obamacare-pot-guns-and-drones/'
    >>> article = Article(url)

.. code-block:: pycon

    >>> article.download()

    >>> article.html
    '<!DOCTYPE HTML><html itemscope itemtype="http://...'

.. code-block:: pycon

    >>> article.parse()

    >>> article.authors
    ['Leigh Ann Caldwell', 'John Honway']

    >>> article.publish_date
    datetime.datetime(2013, 12, 30, 0, 0)

    >>> article.text
    'Washington (CNN) -- Not everyone subscribes to a New Year's resolution...'

    >>> article.top_image
    'http://someCDN.com/blah/blah/blah/file.png'

    >>> article.movies
    ['http://youtube.com/path/to/link.com', ...]

.. code-block:

sources.name: auchenberg/volkswagen
sources.readme_snippet:
# volkswagen

Volkswagen detects when your tests are being run in a CI server, and
makes them pass.

[![Build status](https://travis-ci.org/auchenberg/volkswagen.svg?branch=master)](https://travis-ci.org/auchenberg/volkswagen)
[![js-standard-style](https://img.shields.io/badge/code%20style-standard-brightgreen.svg?style=flat)](https://github.com/feross/standard)
[![volkswagen status](https://auchenberg.github.io/volkswagen/volkswagen_ci.svg?v=1)](https://github.com/auchenberg/volkswagen)

![](https://auchenberg.github.io/volkswagen/illustration.gif)

## Why?

If you want your software to be adopted by Americans, good tests scores
from the CI server are very important. Volkswagen uses a defeat device to
detect when it's being tested in a CI server and will automatically
reduce errors to an acceptable level for the tests to pass. This will
allow you to spend _less_ time worrying about testing and _more_ time
enjoying the good life as a trustful software developer.

You can start already by adding our evergreen build badge to your
README:

[![Volkswagen status](https://auchenberg.github.io/volkswagen/volkswagen_ci.svg)](https://github.com/auchenberg/volkswagen)

Markdown snippet:

```md
[![volkswagen status](https://auchenberg.github.io/volkswagen/volkswagen_ci.svg?v=1)](https://github.com/auchenberg/volkswagen)
```

## Installation

```
npm install volkswagen
```

## Usage

Just require volkswagen somewhere in your code-base - maybe in your main
test file:

```js
require('volkswagen')
```

## Project status

CI servers detected:

- [Travis CI](http://travis-ci.org)
- [CircleCI](http://circleci.com)
- [Jenkins CI](https://jenkins-ci.org)
- [Hudson](http://hudson-ci.org)
- [Bamboo](https://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo)
- [TeamCity](https://www.jetbrains.com/teamcity/)
- [Team Foundation Server](https://www.visualstudio.com/en-us/products/tfs-overview-vs.aspx)
- [Visual Studio Online CI](https://www.visualstudio.com/en-us/products/what-is-visual-studio-online-vs.asp

blueprint.title: GitRecombo â€” Outâ€‘ofâ€‘Scale Blueprint
blueprint.summary: Recombination of recent GitHub innovations with long-tail exploration, health/reputation signals, and optional semantic relevance.
blueprint.architecture_ascii:
[1] modelcontextprotocol/servers  â†’  [2] Genesis-Embodied-AI/Genesis  â†’  [3] emilk/egui  â†’  [4] harness/harness  â†’  [5] mifi/lossless-cut  â†’  [6] pear-devs/pear-desktop  â†’  [7] exo-explore/exo  â†’  [8] veggiemonk/awesome-docker  â†’  [9] vadimdemedes/ink  â†’  [10] avelino/awesome-go  â†’  [11] microsoft/terminal  â†’  [12] seleniumbase/SeleniumBase  â†’  [13] jeecgboot/JeecgBoot  â†’  [14] codelucas/newspaper  â†’  [15] vuejs/awesome-vue  â†’  [16] alexandresanlim/Badges4-README.md-Profile  â†’  [17] vsouza/awesome-ios  â†’  [18] auchenberg/volkswagen
            â†“
        [ Orchestrator ]
why_it_works: Novelty + Health + Author signals + Semantic relevance elevate hidden gems.
Diversity bonus avoids conceptual duplicates when embeddings are enabled.
Permissive licensing keeps integration safe and fast.
